data.title: Jonathon D. Svendsen
data.meta_description: Posts about Jules Verne written by jonathondsvendsen
data.text:
Sorry for the lateness of this post. I wanted to thank you again, dear and loyal readers for taking the time out to read my blog. head into 2023, I want to take a moment to thank you, my loyal … Continue reading →

No matter how advanced humanity becomes, even with such modern technological marvels as space shuttles, or submarines there are just certain traditions and even superstitions continually in play. For example, since the Apollo 13 mission, no NASA space flight has … Continue reading →

Few words conjure the idea of a consummate leader more than the title of “Captain.” To be a captain is to be perceived as a leader of men, and a parental figure to the crew who would be willing to … Continue reading →

Every good crew, especially on the high seas needs a man of action. A ship may need a good captain to lead them through the maelstrom, and the protagonist narrator of the maritime adventures may provide us with a perspective … Continue reading →

At their core there isn’t very much separating the early science fiction adventures by the likes of HG Wells, Jules Verne, CS Lewis or Edgar Rice Burroughs from the other thrilling adventure novels of the 19th century. The books themselves … Continue reading →

Since 2012, Jonathon D. Svendsen has shared a total of 19 essay anthologies on his blog, looking at assorted modern day myths and other classic stories. This spring, he will embark on his twentieth essay and anthology and what … Continue reading →
